definition: to make a fool of oneself
noisy/cacophonous/to make noise/to disturb/to vent (feelings)/to fall ill/to have an attack (of sickness)/to go in (for some activity)/to joke
laugh/smile/CL:個|个[ge4]
dialect/language/spoken words/speech/talk/words/conversation/what sb said/CL:種|种[zhong3],席[xi2],句[ju4],口[kou3],番[fan1]

sentences.english: You can always rely on him making a fool of himself.
sentences.chinese: 你可以想象他一定會鬧笑話。

sentences.english: No more beef fingers, no more drama from now on, I promise.
sentences.chinese: 不再豎中指，不再鬧笑話，我保證。

sentences.english: Don't make a fool of yourself anymore.
If you pretend to know what you don't know, you'll only make a fool of yourself.
Such stereotypes often lead to unusual and sometimes amusing situations.
sentences.chinese: 這種成見常常會引發一些怪事，有時還會鬧笑話。

definition: please excuse me for not complying/to politely decline
improvisation
lit. to settle accounts after autumn/settle scores at an opportune moment (idiom)
to refute/to demolish (an argument, theory etc)
Please do as you wish!/You are welcome to do whatever you like!/Please make yourself at home.
to display one's slight skill before an expert (idiom)
lit. small belly, chicken's gut (idiom); narrow-minded/petty
bossy and domineering/throwing one's weight about
(slang) (Tw) to bullshit/to fool
grand dreams/unrealistic ideas (idiom)
protective coloration/camouflage
to take advantage of one's position to bully people (idiom)/to kick people around
to nod one's head and bow (idiom); bowing and scraping/unctuous fawning
chicken-hearted (idiom)/gutless
foolish talk/nonsense
product placement
